subject: Re: R: [junit] gui testing
msgSnippet: When somebody shows up on this mailing list and asks the vague question, How can I test a gui, should I answer from this perspective? ... -- Robert Koss,
messageBody:
When somebody shows up on this mailing list and asks the vague question,
"How can I test a gui," should I answer from this perspective?



On 6/11/02 8:12 AM, "Timothy Wall" <twall@...> wrote:

> Or try this (a real-world case):
>
> I'm editing a field in my form, and something happens asynchronously
> such that the action of editing a field in the form is no longer valid.
> There are several options of what to do at the interface level (with
> varying degrees of UI acceptableness and programmatic complexity), but
> your mediator knows nothing of the editor, nor of how it relates to the
> form, or of any other transient objects that may be introduced (dialogs,
> swapped-out panes) in order to rectify the situation.
>
> The programmatic easy-to-test solution may not be the one required for
> usability of the UI.
>
> On Tuesday, June 11, 2002, at 09:59 AM, Luca Sfarzo wrote:
>
>> Hi think that using a mediator could guarantee you from separating the
>> mechanism for handling data that lies deep in the "core" of your
>> application
>> from the GUI details, but sometimes the behavior of a single form can be
>> driven by a many-state state machine (so being very complex) and some
>> transitions should rely on some other data liyng somewhere else in the
>> depth
>> of the application.
>> Here the problem arises.
>>
>> One example should be if I would test my GUI behavior when something
>> somewhere else changes.
>>
>> I.e. I'm editing some fields to be sent later to a server and the
>> connection
>> goes down. Ok the mediator can do the great part of the job but what if
>> my
>> current form should let me save the data into a file in order to
>> retrieve
>> them later? That kind of knowledge lies inside the form (it's its own
>> responsibility, above all!) while the constraints come from the outer
>> world.
>>
>> Hi,
>> Luca Sfarzo
>> TRSNeapolis
>> Tel:+390815272842
>>
>>
>>
>>
>> -----Messaggio originale-----
>> Da: Bob Koss [mailto:koss@...]
>> Inviato: martedi 11 giugno 2002 15.37
>> A: junit@yahoogroups.com
>> Oggetto: Re: [junit] gui testing
>>
>>
>> On 6/11/02 7:28 AM, "Michael Silverstein" <msilverstein@...>
>> wrote:
>>
>>>
>>>
>>> Bob Koss [mailto:koss@...] wrote:
>>>> But if we use Mediator to decouple the gui controls, we may as
>>>> well delegate
>>>> everything to the Mediator and leave the gui stupid. The Mediator can
>>>> be
>>>> unit tested just like any other class, and doesn't need the gui since
>>>> all
>>>> communication is done through interfaces.
>>>
>>> That notwithstanding, you still need to test the connection between the
>>> mediator and your GUI. There's still plenty of room for error there.
>>
>>
>> I'm trying to understand your concern. I can test that the Mediator
>> send the
>> right message with the right parameters at the right time. The code in
>> the
>> gui (let's say a Dialog box just to be concrete) that responds to this
>> message is one or two lines of code which IMO, can't break.
>>
>> Can you show me in a few lines of code where there is room for error
>> between
>> the Mediator and the gui/dialog/whatever?
>>
>>
